We will focus on the first part of that statement and explore whether the Clinton Foundation has already helped make HIV/AIDS drugs more affordable for 9 million people. The Foundation ' s work in the area of HIV/AIDS treatment dates back to 2002 with the establishment of the Clinton Initiative for Access to Health. This was a time when some countries paid $1,000 or more to treat each AIDS patient. The main objective was to reduce bulk procurement costs. The programme has strengthened both the supply of raw materials for the manufacture of medicines and tenders for the supply of the final product.
